choices.text: Cancellous bone is more vascular than cortical bone
Both cancellous bone in an adult are formed of lamellar bone
Cancellous bone heals poorly after a fracture when compared to cortical bone
Cancellous bone has more bone cells, while cortical has fewer bone cells

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In reality, cancellous bone heals faster and more efficiently than cortical bone.
  • This is due to:
    • Higher vascularity
    • Greater surface area
    • Abundance of osteogenic cells
  • Both cancellous and cortical bone in an adult is formed of lamellar bone (Option B)

Differences between cancellous and cortical bone:

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Periosteum does not contain Osteoclasts are seen in the endosteum
  • Endosteum is made up of a single layer; however, it is thicker than the periosteum.

Explanation of other options:

Endosteum has only one layer (Option B): The endosteum is composed of a single layer of flattened osteoprogenitor cells and sometimes osteoblasts or osteoclasts, especially in active bone remodelling.

Endosteum has osteoprogenitor cells (Option C): These osteoprogenitor cells are precursors to osteoblasts and are essential for bone growth and repair.

Periosteum has osteoclasts (Opion D): The cellular inner layer of the periosteum may contain osteoclasts along with osteoblasts and osteoprogenitor cells, especially in regions of active bone remodelling.

choices.text: Around the growth plate in children
Cancellous bone of the femur in adults

questions.text: Woven bone is found in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Woven bone is immature bone seen during embryonal development. Woven bone is weak and is slowly replaced by stronger lamellar bone during development. Woven bone is almost completely replaced by 2 years age of.
  • Hence, it is not seen in cancellous bone ofthe femur in adults
  • However, there are conditions where woven bone can be seen even after 2 years of age. Eg
    1. Around the growth plates in growing children (Option A)
    2. During fracture healing (Option D)
    3. Pathologies of bone
      • Paget's disease
      • Fibrous dysplasia (Option C)
      • Osteogenic tumours - osteogenic sarcoma, osteoblastoma, etc.

Explanation:

  • Osteoid is the organic part of bone, consisting mainly of collagen fibres, proteoglycans, and glycoproteins.
  • In other words, it is bone without the mineral component, so calcium hydroxyapatite is not present in it.
  • Osteoid consists of a central haversian canal surrounded by concentric lamellae with a cement line forming a boundary.

Composition of bone

Explanation of other options:

Osteocytes (Option A): Mature bone cells embedded within the lacunae of osteoid.

Haversian canal (Option B): Central channel within osteons containing blood vessels and nerves; present in the osteoid matrix before mineralisation.

Protein matrix (Option C): Organic collagen-rich framework of osteoid that later becomes mineralised.

questions.text: Type 1 collagen is found in all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Type I collagen is seen in the following skeletal tissues
    1. Annulus fibrosus of the intervertebral disc (Option B)
    2. Bone (Option D)
    3. Menisci (Option A)
  • Articular cartilage contains type II collagen

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presents for evaluation of delayed fracture healing. His bone biopsy reveals active matrix formation with secretion of non-collagenous proteins such as osteonectin and osteocalcin, both of which are involved in bone mineralisation.
Which of the following cells is responsible for producing these proteins?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Osteoblast is the bone-building cell. It produces all the proteins needed to make up bone tissue, which includes type I collagen, osteocalcin, osteonectin, etc
  • It also produces an important enzyme, Alkaline phosphatase, which can be used as a marker for bone formation.

Explanation of other options:

Osteoclasts (Option A) are involved in bone resorption, not matrix production.

Osteocytes (Option B) are mature osteoblasts embedded in bone matrix, involved in mechanosensation, but not protein synthesis.

Osteoprogenitor cells (Option C) are stem cells that differentiate into osteoblasts but do not directly secrete matrix proteins.

choices.text: It is responsible for bone resorption

questions.text: Which of the following statements about osteoclasts is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • ALP is produced by osteoblasts
  • Osteoclasts
    • Bone resorbing cell (Option A)
    • Formed by the fusion of monocyte progenitor cells
    • Least common cell of bone
    • Multinucleated
    • Has ruffled borders (Option C)
    • Rests in Howship's lacunae (Option B)
    • Secrete
      • Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is a marker for bone destruction.
    • Osteon is the basic structural unit of bone

choices.text: It states that compression along the physis will inhibit growth..
It states that circumferential strain will increase bone girth.
It states that bone remodels according to external stresses.
It states that osteoclasts are responsible for bone remodelling.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Wolff's law?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Wolff's law states that bone remodels according to the external forces acting on it.
  • Areas subjected to increased stress develop stronger bone, while areas with reduced stress may undergo bone resorption.

Explanation of other options:

It states that compression along the physis will inhibit (Option A): This refers to Heuter-Volkmann Law, not Wolff's Law. Heuter-Volkmann principle explains how growth at the physis is inhibited by increased compression and stimulated by tension.

It states that circumferential strain will increase bone girth (Option B): While bone modelling can occur in response to strain, this statement is an oversimplification and not the definition of Wolff's Law. It may relate more to periosteal response than to Wolff's principle directly.

It states that osteoclasts are responsible for bone remodelling (Option D): While osteoclasts play a role in bone resorption, and osteoblasts in formation, Wolff's Law is about mechanical influence on bone structure, not about cellular responsibility.

questions.text: A Tide mark is seen in which of the following tissues?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The tide mark is a histological feature seen in articular (hyaline) cartilage.
  • It is a basophilic line observed between the calcified cartilage zone and the non-calcified cartilage
  • This demarcation represents the front of active endochondral ossification and is significant in understanding cartilage degeneration and osteoarthritis.

Explanation of other options:

Cancellous bone (Option A): Cancellous (spongy) bone has a trabecular structure but does not exhibit a tide mark.

Cortical bone (Option B): Cortical bone consists of osteons and lamellae, but no tide mark.

Woven bone (Option C): Woven bone is immature bone with a haphazard collagen arrangement, and it lacks a tide mark.

questions.text: The fibres that connect the periosteum to the cortex are known as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sharpey's fibres are collagenous fibres that extend from the fibrous layer of the periosteum into the underlying cortical bone.
  • They function to anchor the periosteum firmly to the cortical bone, thereby stabilising the attachment of tendons, ligaments, and joint capsules.

Explanation of other options:

Nodes of Ranvier (Option A): These are gaps in the myelin sheath of axons in the nervous system; not related to bone.

Cords of Ranvier (Option B): This is not an anatomically recognised term in bone or neural anatomy. Likely a distractor.

Volkmann's fibres (Option D): A misnomer here. Volkmann's canals, not fibres, are microscopic channels in cortical bone that connect Haversian canals, carrying blood vessels and nerves.
